description: 1595–1605; From Late Latin sōliloquium in the title of St. Augustine's Soliloquiorum libri duo ("Two Books of Soliloquies"), from sōlus (“only, sole”) + loquor (“I speak”).

entries.meaning: (drama) The act of a character speaking to themselves so as to reveal their thoughts to the audience.
examples: At the end of the second act the main villain gave a soliloquy detailing his plans to attack the protagonist.

entries.meaning: (authorship) A speech or written discourse in this form.

verbs.description: soliloquy (third-person singular simple present soliloquies, present participle soliloquying or soliloquing, simple past and past participle soliloquied)
